study_plan_entry.title: Light and the built environment - impact on circadian physiology in humans (EDNE)

free_text.Learning outcomes: The course will outline the state of the art of chronobiological research in a variety of fields, such as physiology, genetics and behavioral psychology. Hereby, the course will focus on the impact of light on animals and humans. It will further accentuate the connection between disciplines such as architecture, (day)- lighting design and medicine with possible implications on human health.  [br/]
free_text.Content: 1.Introduction and history of chronobiology, first experiments and methods[br/]2. The endogenous biological clock[br/]3. Peripheral  circadian oscillators[br/]4. Visual processing of light (image forming and non-image forming visual system)[br/]5. Impact of light in animals (saisonality, ultradian rhythms)[br/]6. Impact of  (day)light in humans part 1 (circadian rhythms, sleep-wake activity)[br/]7. Impact of light in humans part 2 (behavior, cognitive performance)[br/]8. A circadian clock in each cell - molecular approaches[br/]9. Light in shift work and jet lag[br/]10. Light therapy for patients[br/]11. Light and architecture[br/]12. Summary, conclusion, general discussion and future directions[br/]13. Visit of a chronobiological laboratory[br/]14. student presentations[br/][br/]
free_text.Keywords: light, circadian rhythms, sleep-wake cycle, daylight, architecture, shift work[br/]
